description_intro: This script teaches you AWS IoT Rules Engine concepts:
rules_concepts: â€¢ IoT Rules Engine SQL syntax and message routing
â€¢ Topic filtering with SELECT, FROM, and WHERE clauses
â€¢ Republish actions and IAM role configuration
â€¢ Rule lifecycle management (create, enable, disable, delete)
â€¢ Real-time rule testing and validation
â€¢ Complete API details for each operation
debug_features: â€¢ Enhanced AWS IoT API logging
â€¢ Detailed rule payload and IAM operations

rules_foundation.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: IoT Rules Engine
rules_foundation.content: The AWS IoT Rules Engine processes and routes messages from your devices using SQL-like queries. Rules can filter, transform, and route messages to various AWS services like Lambda, DynamoDB, or S3. This enables real-time data processing, alerting, and integration with your broader AWS architecture without requiring device-side logic changes.
rules_foundation.next: We will create and manage IoT rules for message processing

rules_inventory.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Rules Inventory & Management
rules_inventory.content: Listing IoT rules shows you all the message processing logic currently active in your account. Each rule has a name, SQL statement, and actions. This inventory helps you understand your data flow, identify unused rules, and manage your IoT message processing pipeline effectively.
rules_inventory.next: We will list all IoT rules in your account

rule_analysis.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Rule Analysis & Troubleshooting
rule_analysis.content: Describing a rule reveals its complete configuration including SQL query, actions, and metadata. This detailed view is essential for troubleshooting message routing issues, understanding rule logic, and verifying that rules are configured correctly for your use case.
rule_analysis.next: We will examine a specific rule's configuration

rule_creation.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Rule Creation & Message Routing
rule_creation.content: Creating IoT rules defines how messages from your devices are processed and routed. Rules use SQL-like syntax to filter and transform messages, then trigger actions like storing data, invoking functions, or sending notifications. This enables real-time data processing without device-side changes.
rule_creation.next: We will create a new IoT rule with SQL and actions

rule_testing.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Rule Testing & Validation
rule_testing.content: Testing rules with sample messages validates your SQL logic and ensures rules behave as expected before deploying to production. This helps catch filtering errors, syntax issues, and logic problems that could cause message processing failures or unexpected behavior.
rule_testing.next: We will test a rule with sample MQTT messages

rule_lifecycle.title: ğŸ“š LEARNING MOMENT: Rule Lifecycle Operations
rule_lifecycle.content: Managing rules includes enabling, disabling, and deleting them. Disabling rules stops message processing without losing configuration, while deleting removes them permanently. This lifecycle management is crucial for maintaining, updating, and troubleshooting your IoT data processing pipeline.
rule_lifecycle.next: We will manage rule status and lifecycle
